_exec_summary.SummaryText:
I.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY POLICIES

     Penobscot McCrum recognizes management's responsibility to protecting it's employees, equipment, property, and the environment. The safety and health of all personnel are very important.  The control of ammonia release incidents has been and will continue to be the basic responsibility of all Penobscot McCrum personnel who operate their Ammonia Refrigeration Process.

     The Penobscot McCrum PSM/RMP program assigns and documents the specific responsibilities for developing, implementing and integrating the OSHA PSM and the EPA RMP standards into its Ammonia Operating and Management Systems.  The Penobscot McCrum PSM/RMP program focuses attention on "Making PSM/RMP the way we manage our ammonia based refrigeration system" rather than a project we expect to complete and put on the shelf when the filing date has passed.

     Penobscot/McCrum believes that Employee Participation is the key to a successful PSM/RMP program.  Operating level employees, particularly the Refrigeration Manager has been deeply involved and he (along with the Refrigeration System Operators) assume the major responsibility for operating the Hazardous Material process safely.

     The Penobscot McCrum Emergency Action Plan has been developed in house and is seeking assistance from and  cooperation with the local Public Emergency Response Agency.  All Penobscot McCrum employees have received documented Emergency Action Training.


II.  STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

     Penobscot McCrum operates an Ammonia Refrigeration System.  Ammonia is a common industrial chemical with applications in a large number of industries such as Agriculture, Water Treatment, Food Storage Warehouses, Pharmaceuticals, Heat Treating and many, many more.  Ammonia has been listed by both EPA and OSHA as Hazardous Substance.


III. SUMMARY OF WORST CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

Dispersion cloud modeling studies have been perfo

rmed as required by PSM/RMP regulations and the information developed has been used in the preparation of the Technical Studies and other Documentation as required by the PSM/RMP Regulation.


IV.   DESCRIPTION OF THE Penobscot McCrum ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

     Penobscot McCrum conducts annual in house emergency action training and is seeking a response relationship the local Public Emergency Response Agency to practice and update a unified response to an unintentional ammonia release situation.

     Penobscot McCrum conducts an annual PSM/RMP progress audit of their PSM/RMP program to identify strengths and weaknesses and make improvements. Penobscot McCrum considers the PSM/RMP manuals to be a "living" documents that must be updated and revised regularly to maintain their viability and usefulness.

     Penobscot McCrum emphasizes and insists on "employee participation" from their ammonia process operators in all aspects of the development, implementation, and integration of their PSM/RMP program.

    Penobscot McCrum provides a comprehensive, computer based, user friendly training program and management system with "one-on-one" teacher involvement in specific training modules for each ammonia process employee.

     Penobscot McCrum maintains a pro-active "open-door" policy toward neighbors and concerned community citizens.  Facility tours and risk management discussions are scheduled and conducted upon written request.

V.  FIVE YEAR ACCIDENTAL RELEASE HISTORY

     There have been no releases of ammonia during the past five years that resulted in an injury, or that had an off-site impact, or that resulted in significant property damage either on-site or off-site.

VI. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

     Facility employees have been trained to respond to accidental ammonia releases with ?defensive? evacuate, give notice and assemble response stragegy.  The site emergency plan is being coordinated with local Public Emergency  Responders.

VII. PLA

NNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

      Penobscot McCrum recognizes that even good PSM/RMP Programs require constant attention and improvement.  The PSM/RMP program is considered to be a set of "living" documents and procedures that will require constant attention, development, and revision before "Safety" truly becomes "second nature".

     Penobscot McCrum expects to improve PSM/RMP and safety performance by emphasizing the following elements of their PSM/RMP Program:

(1)   EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION:  Employee Participation is the "Key" to a successful program. Ammonia Process Managers and Operators have been deeply involved in Verifying P&ID's, Developing and updating the Standard Operating Procedures, and performing the documented Preventive Maintenance Inspections.

(2)    EXPANCED USE OF THEIR PSM/RMP WEB-SITE:  The Penobscot McCrum PSM/RMP Program is:  (a) computer based,  (b)user friendly,  (c) includes "one-on-one" involvement with specified and qualified trainers,  (d) written to minimize paperwork and maximize documentation, and  (e) written to be understood and used by both Ammonia Managers and Process Operators.  The web-site makes all information developed by the PSM/RMP Program available to all employees who have a User Name and Password.  All Penobscot McCrum employees who operate the ammonia system have an assigned User Name and Password. 

(3)  PROCESS HAZARDS ANALYSIS: All recommendations developed during the Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) were designed to improve the safety performance of the Ammonia Refrigeration System.  Penobscot McCrum will evaluate each PHA recommendation.  Each recommendation has been installed and will reduce the possibility of a release and/or mitigate the consequences of an unintentional release.

(4) AUDITS:   Programs are audited Tri-Annually as required by the OSHA PSM to improve Safety Performance as well as to verify compliance with the PSM/RMP Regulations. 

(5)  STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES:  SOP's are certified ann

ually to be current and correct.  They are revised as often as necessary to keep them current and correct.

(6)  TRAINING:  Documented Orientation Training (both classroom and On-the-Job) is provided employees before Ammonia related work assignments are given.  Renewal training, including documented training tests, are provided annually.

(7)  PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE INSPECTIONS:  Critical Ammonia Equipment is routinely inspected and maintained according to manufacturer?s recommendations.
